title: Modular Arithmetic
content:
Module 1, Lesson 10: Modular Arithmetic

The Hook

Modular arithmetic is arithmetic on a "clock" — numbers wrap around after reaching a modulus m. We write a ≡ b (mod m) if m divides (a – b). Clock arithmetic (mod 12), weekday calculations (mod 7), and cryptographic algorithms all rely on modular arithmetic.

The Concept

1. Congruence

a ≡ b (mod m) means a and b have the same remainder when divided by m. For example, 17 ≡ 5 (mod 12) because 17 – 5 = 12. Congruence is an equivalence relation: reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

2. Arithmetic Operations mod m

If a ≡ a' and b ≡ b' (mod m), then a + b ≡ a' + b', a – b ≡ a' – b', and a × b ≡ a' × b' (all mod m). This makes modular arithmetic a valid algebraic structure (a ring).

3. Modular Inverses

The modular inverse of a (mod m) is the integer x such that ax ≡ 1 (mod m). It exists if and only if GCD(a, m) = 1. The extended Euclidean algorithm finds it. Modular inverses are essential in RSA cryptography.

4. Fermat's Little Theorem

If p is prime and GCD(a, p) = 1, then aᵖ⁻¹ ≡ 1 (mod p). This theorem is used to compute modular exponentiation efficiently and forms the basis of primality testing algorithms.

The Illustration

Modular arithmetic provides a powerful framework for clock-like calculations. You learned congruence, modular operations, modular inverses, and Fermat's Little Theorem, all of which are central to modern cryptography.
